<p>We are trying to factor out the two highlighted lines into a separate library, renaming <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">y</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.19444em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">y</span></span></span></span></span> into <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">s</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">s</span></span></span></span></span> in the process. But <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">s</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">s</span></span></span></span></span> can only exist inside the private scope of the new library, while<br>
there still exists a “dangling reference” <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">y</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.19444em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">y</span></span></span></span></span> in the original library.</p>
<p>Speaking more generally about PRGs, suppose we have a call to <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>G</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">G</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">G</span></span></span></span></span> somewhere and want to argue that its outputs are pseudorandom. We can only express this call to <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>G</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">G</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">G</span></span></span></span></span> in<br>
terms of <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msubsup><mi mathvariant="script">L</mi><mtext>prg-real</mtext><mi>G</mi></msubsup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{L}_{\text{prg-real}}^G</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.26055em; vertical-align: -0.419216em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">L</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.841331em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.41689em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">prg-real</span></span></span></span></span><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathdefault mtight">G</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.419216em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> if the input to <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>G</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">G</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">G</span></span></span></span></span> is uniform and is used nowhere else. That’s not true here – we can’t express one of the calls to <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>G</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">G</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">G</span></span></span></span></span> in terms of <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msubsup><mi mathvariant="script">L</mi><mtext>prg-real</mtext><mi>G</mi></msubsup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{L}_{\text{prg-real}}^G</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.26055em; vertical-align: -0.419216em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">L</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.841331em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.41689em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">prg-real</span></span></span></span></span><span class="" style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathdefault mtight">G</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.419216em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, so we can’t be sure that the outputs of that call to <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>G</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">G</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">G</span></span></span></span></span> look random.</p>
<p>These subtle issues are not limited to PRGs. Every hybrid security proof in this course includes steps where we factor out some statements in terms of some pre-existing library.<br>
Don’t take these steps for granted! They will fail (often because of scoping issues) if the construction isn’t using the building block correctly. You should always treat such “factoring out” steps as “sanity checks” for your proof.</p>
<h3 id="a-concrete-attack-on-h_2">A Concrete Attack on <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.83333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.301108em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.08125em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></h3>
<p>So far, we’ve only demonstrated that we get stuck when trying to prove the security of <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.83333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.301108em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.08125em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>. But that doesn’t necessarily mean that <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.83333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.301108em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.08125em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is insecure – it could mean that we’re just not clever enough to see a different security proof. To show that <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.83333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.301108em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.08125em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is actually insecure, we must demonstrate a successful distinguishing attack.</p>
<p>Attacking a PRG amounts tofinding “patterns” in their outputs. Does <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.83333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.301108em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.08125em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> have a pattern in its outputs? Yes, in this case the pattern is that if you write the output in the form <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>x</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">∥</mi><mi>y</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">∥</mi><mi>u</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">∥</mi><mi>v</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">∥</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">x\|y\|u\|v\|</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">x</span><span class="mord">∥</span><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">y</span><span class="mord">∥</span><span class="mord mathdefault">u</span><span class="mord">∥</span><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">v</span><span class="mord">∥</span></span></span></span></span>, then <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>u</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">∥</mi><mi>v</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">u\|v</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">u</span><span class="mord">∥</span><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">v</span></span></span></span></span> is always equal to <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>G</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">G(y)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">G</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">y</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>. The calling program can check for this condition, which is unlikely to happen for truly uniform values.</p>
<p>You may wonder, is it legal for the calling program to compute <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>G</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">G(y)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">G</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">y</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>? Well, <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>G</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">G</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">G</span></span></span></span></span> is a publicly known algorithm (Kerckhoffs’ principle!), and y is right there as part of the input. Nothing prevents the calling program from running <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>G</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">G</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">G</span></span></span></span></span> “in its head.”<sup class="footnote-ref"><a href="#fn4" id="fnref4">4</a></sup></p>
<p><strong>Claim 5.6</strong><br>
<em>Construction <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.83333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.301108em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.08125em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is <strong>not</strong> a secure PRG, even if <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>G</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">G</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">G</span></span></span></span></span> is.</em></p>
<p><strong>Proof</strong><br>
Consider the following distinguisher <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{A}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">A</span></span></span></span></span></span>:</p>
<p><span class="katex--display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><menclose notation="top bottom left right"><mtable rowspacing="0.6599999999999999em" columnalign="left" columnspacing="1em"><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">∥</mi><mi>y</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">∥</mi><mi>u</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">∥</mi><mi>v</mi><mo>:</mo><mo>=</mo><mtext>QUERY()</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mtext>return&nbsp;</mtext><mi>G</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mover><mo><mo>=</mo></mo><mo stretchy="false">?</mo></mover><mi>u</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">∥</mi><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr></mtable></menclose></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">

<p>In the attack on <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.83333em; margin-left: -0.08125em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is insecure even if <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>G</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">G</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">G</span></span></span></span></span> is the best PRG in the world! It’s insecure because of the incorrect way<br>
it <em>uses</em> <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>G</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">G</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">G</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>From now on in this book, we’ll be studying higher-level constructions that are assembled from various building blocks — in this chapter, fancy PRGs constructed from simpler<br>
PRGs. “Security” means: if the building blocks are secure then the construction is secure. “Insecurity” means: <em>even if the building blocks are secure</em>, the construction can be insecure.<br>
So when you’re showing insecurity, you shouldn’t directly attack the building blocks! You should assume the building blocks are secure and attack <em>the way that the building blocks<br>
are being used</em>.</p>
<h2 id="star-5.5-applications-stream-cipher--symmetric-ratchet"><span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mo>⋆</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\star</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.46528em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">⋆</span></span></span></span></span> 5.5 Applications: Stream Cipher &amp; Symmetric Ratchet</h2>
<p>The PRG-feedback construction can be generalized in a natural way, by continuing to feed part of <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>G</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">’</mi><mi>s</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">G’s</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">G</span><span class="mord">’</span><span class="mord mathdefault">s</span></span></span></span></span> output into <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>G</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">G</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">G</span></span></span></span></span> again. The proof works in the same way as for the previous construction — the security of <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>G</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">G</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">G</span></span></span></span></span> is applied one at a time to each application of <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>G</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">G</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">G</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>

<em>If G is a secure length-doubling PRG, then for any <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">n</span></span></span></span></span> (polynomial function of <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\lambda</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; <p><span class="katex--display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mstyle mathcolor="red"><mtext>Image&nbsp;screenshot&nbsp;here</mtext></mstyle></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">

<p>The fact that this chain of PRGs can be extended indefinitely gives another useful functionality:</p>
<p><strong>Definition 5.8 (Stream cipher)</strong><br>
<em>A <strong>stream cipher</strong> is an algorithm <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>G</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">G</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">G</span></span></span></span></span> that takes a seed s and length <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">ℓ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\ell</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">ℓ</span></span></span></span></span> as input, and outputs a string. It should satisfy the following requirements:</em></p>
<ol>
<li><em><span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>G</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">ℓ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">G(s,\ell)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">G</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathdefault">s</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.166667em;"></span><span class="mord">ℓ</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> is a string of length <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">ℓ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\ell</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">ℓ</span></span></span></span></span>.</em></li>
<li><em>If <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>&lt;</mo><mi>j</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">i &lt; j</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69862em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">i</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.277778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.85396em; vertical-align: -0.19444em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.05724em;">j</span></span></span></span></span>, then <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>G</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>i</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">G(s,i)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">G</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathdefault">s</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.166667em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">i</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> is a prefix of <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>G</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>j</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">G(s,j)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">G</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathdefault">s</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.166667em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.05724em;">j</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>.</em></li>
<li><em>For each <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">n</span></span></span></span></span>, the function <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>G</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mo>⋅</mo><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">G(\cdot,n)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">G</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">⋅</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.166667em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">n</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> is a secure PRG.</em></li>
</ol>
<p>Because of the 2nd rule, you might want to think about a single infinitely long string that is the <em>limit</em> of <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>G</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">G(s,n)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">G</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathdefault">s</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.166667em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">n</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> as <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">n</span></span></span></span></span> goes to infinity. The finite-length strings <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>G</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">G(s,n)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">G</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathdefault">s</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.166667em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">n</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> are all the prefixes of this infinitely long string.</p>
<p>The PRG-feedback construction can be used to construct a secure stream cipher in the natural way: given seed <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">s</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">s</span></span></span></span></span> and length <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">ℓ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\ell</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">ℓ</span></span></span></span></span>, keep iterating the PRG-feedback main loop until <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">ℓ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\ell</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord">ℓ</span></span></span></span></span> bits have been generated.</p>
<p><span class="katex--display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mstyle mathcolor="red"><mtext>Image&nbsp;screenshot&nbsp;here</mtext></mstyle></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
\textcolor{red}{\text{Image screenshot here}}
</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.88888em; vertical-align: -0.19444em;"></span><span class="mord text" style="color: red;"><span class="mord" style="color: red;">Image&nbsp;screenshot&nbsp;here</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<h3 id="symmetric-ratchet">Symmetric Ratchet</h3>
<p>Suppose Alice &amp; Bob share a symmetric key <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">k</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.03148em;">k</span></span></span></span></span> and are using a secure messaging app to exchange messages over a long period of time. Later in the course we will see techniques that Alice &amp; Bob could use to securely encrypt many messages using a single key. However,<br>
suppose Bob’s device is compromised and an attacker learns <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">k</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.03148em;">k</span></span></span></span></span>. Then the attacker can decrypt all past, present, and future ciphertexts that it saw!</p>
<p>Alice &amp; Bob can protect against such a key compromise by using the PRG-feedback stream cipher to constantly “update” their shared key. Suppose they do the following,<br>
starting with their shared key <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">k</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.03148em;">k</span></span></span></span></span>:</p>
<ul>
<li>They use <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">k</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.69444em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault" style="margin-right: 0.03148em;">k</span></span></span></span></span> to seed a chain of length-doubling PRGs, and both obtain the same stream of pseudorandom keys <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mo>…</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">t1, t2,\ldots</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.83888em; vertical-align: -0.19444em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">t</span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.166667em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">t</span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.166667em;"></span><span class="minner">…</span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li>They use <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">t_i</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.76508em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathdefault">t</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.311664em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathdefault mtight">i</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> as a key to send/receive the ith message. The details of the encryption are not relevant to this example.</li>
<li>After making a call to the PRG, they erase the PRG input from memory, and only remember the PRG’s output. After using <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">t_i</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.76508em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathdefault">t</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.311664em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathdefault mtight">i</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> to send/receive a message, they also erase it from memory.</li>
</ul>
<p>This way of using and forgetting a sequence of keys is called a <strong>symmetric ratchet</strong>.</p>
<p><strong>Construction 5.9 (Symm Ratchet)</strong></p>
<p><span class="katex--display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mstyle mathcolor="red"><mtext>Image&nbsp;screenshot&nbsp;here</mtext></mstyle></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">
\textcolor{red}{\text{Image screenshot here}}
</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.88888em; vertical-align: -0.19444em;"></span><span class="mord text" style="color: red;"><span class="mord" style="color: red;">Image&nbsp;screenshot&nbsp;here</span></span></span></span></span></span></span><br>
Suppose that an attacker compromises Bob’s device after <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">n</span></span></span></span></span> ciphertexts have been sent. The only value residing in memory is <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>s</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">s_n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.58056em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathdefault">s</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.151392em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathdefault mtight">n</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, which the attacker learns. Since <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>G</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">G</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.68333em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">G</span></span></span></span></span> is deterministic, the attacker can now compute <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>t</mi><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo separator="true">,</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo separator="true">,</mo><mo>…</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">t_{n+1}, t_{n+2},\ldots</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.823411em; vertical-align: -0.208331em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathdefault">t</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.301108em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathdefault mtight">n</span><span class="mbin mtight">+</span><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.208331em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.166667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathdefault">t</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.301108em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathdefault mtight">n</span><span class="mbin mtight">+</span><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.208331em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.166667em;"></span><span class="minner">…</span></span></span></span></span> in the usual way and decrypt all future ciphertexts that are sent.</p>
<p>However, we can show that the attacker learns no information about <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo separator="true">,</mo><mo>…</mo><mo separator="true">,</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">t_1,\ldots, t_n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.80952em; vertical-align: -0.19444em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathdefault">t</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.301108em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.166667em;"></span><span class="minner">…</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.166667em;"></span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.166667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathdefault">t</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.151392em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathdefault mtight">n</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> from <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>s</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">s_n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.58056em; By compromising the key <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>s</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">s_n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.58056em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathdefault">s</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.151392em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathdefault mtight">n</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, the adversary only compromises the security of <em>future</em> messages, but not past messages. As promised, we showed that the attacker cannot distinguish the first <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.43056em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mord mathdefault">n</span></span></span></span></span> ciphertexts from random values, even when seeing <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>s</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">s_n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.58056em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathdefault">s</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.151392em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathdefault mtight">n</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>. <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">■</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\ \blacksquare</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em; vertical-align: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord amsrm">■</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>This proof used the uniform-ciphertexts property, but the same logic applies to basically any encryption property you care about — just imagine factoring out the encryption steps in terms of a different library than <span class="katex--inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="script">L</mi><mrow><mtext>ots</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mo>−</mo><mtext>real</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{L}_{\text{ots}\Phi-\text{real}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.891661em; vertical-align: -0.208331em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathcal">L</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.336108em;"><span class="" style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">ots</span></span><span class="mord mtight">Φ</span><span class="mbin mtight">−</span><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">real</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.208331em;"><span class=""></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
